perturbation.explanation: This perturbation alters the Company's obligation to fulfill orders. The original text states the Company will use "reasonable best efforts" to ship orders within a day. The modification states that the company will "guarantee" the delivery no matter the circumstances, but doesn't actually guarantee any actual compensation for these actions. This creates a contradiction if the "Business Plan" dictates a more lenient approach and/or the original text provides a more specific guideline for compensation. There may be ambiguity regarding inventory, logistics, and how those are impacted by the two conflicting goals.

   THE COMPANY WARRANTS MERCHANTABILITY OR FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE OR ANY OTHER WARRANTIES RELATING TO THE PRODUCTS, WHETHER EXPRESS OR IMPLIED. ANY STATEMENTS MADE BY REPRESENTATIVES OF THE COMPANY WITH RESPECT TO THE PRODUCTS DO CONSTITUTE WARRANTIES AND CAN BE RELIED UPON BY THE AGENT.
perturbation.explanation: This perturbation introduces several contradictions regarding warranties. The original text warrants a 12-month shelf life, compliance with all applicable laws and regulations, replacement as the exclusive remedy and denies any reliance on statements outside the written agreement. The modified text reduces the shelf-life warranty to 6 months, warrants compliance with "industry practices" instead of laws, offers a refund instead of a replacement, limits damages to $500 and states that representations made can and do constitute warranties and can be relied upon. There is also a removal of the disclaimer about the company not providing any other warranties of any sort. These conflicting terms create a situation where it's impossible to determine the actual extent or remedy available under the product warranty.
